Waited two years on a waiting list and ended up with the F-350 Lariat with the 6.7L Power Stroke Diesel. Original order was for a Limited Edition, and when we were told the features would be delayed due to manufacturing issues, we changed to the combination above. Was completely blown away at the ride and handling versus our previous heavy-duty truck. Still love that truck, but the F-350 is so much more refined for both on and off-road use. The spaciousness of the cabin versus the other truck was a great surprise as well. Had the typical first year production gremlins that I've experienced in Asian, German, and American vehicles we were early adopters of; comes with the territory and Ford stayed in touch and took care of them as they came up. Never driven anything outside of a military HUMMV that was this confidence-inspiring off-road, towing heavy loads with ease, I mean at the turn of a dial all the towing modes did what was asked of them. Interior noise shouldn't be a surprise to anyone who's owned a heavy-duty truck. Interior materials and drain holes for rinsing out dirt and debris were great. I would love it if Ford made a solid one-piece body like the Ram. No regrets at all. *Edmunds doesn't have the Lariat with the 6.7L Diesel, but that was our combination so maybe they can fix that.

Needed a new truck. I had no intention of buying a heavy-duty vehicle, let alone a Chevrolet. My wife wanted to check out trucks, so I reluctantly agreed. First, we drove some lighter models. Meh. Then she showed me the specs of a Silverado 3500, and I agreed to test drive it. 1. You schedule test drive via online. We found it super convenient. Knew exactly when and where we would be test driving, no waiting in the lot for some pushy salesman. 2. Sign in, Chevrolet rep greets us and lets us look around, then explains to us how to use the features. No sales pushing, just answering all our questions. 3. Supposed to be a 30 min test drive, we couldn't stop, went for an hour. It was thought changing. I went from being a truck skeptic to a Chevrolet enthusiast in 60 min. 4. Went online and bought a truck that afternoon. Again, no scumbag slimy salesman, everything straightforward and easy. 5. Did have to download the app to finish the process to fill out the paperwork. But, this was fine, do it from the living room couch rather than in a crazy office with some sales idiot bugging you to buy some stupid extras. 6. The only hiccup, app prompts you to pay before picking up the truck. I just messaged in the app that I preferred to see the truck before paying. Response, No problem. 7. Pickup fast, efficient, trouble-free. People were great. The whole experience left us thinking, this all works together so well. Everything is well thought out and customer experience well thought out. Truck is just a pleasure to drive. Fun, powerful, quiet, and handles well. Relaxing to drive in traffic. With tax credits, cheaper than a standard pickup. We did get a home charger for the electric version, makes the ownership sooo much better. Just plug it in every night and never worry about range for normal commuting. Day three, first day commuting, we got a weird rock ding and broke the front passenger window. Got home. Called service (they answered fast) and they recommended using the app to schedule service. (They offered to schedule over the phone, but I wanted to try the app). Tried it, flawless to schedule service. Asked you to describe the problem, take some pics and submit. Within minutes, got a message that a mobile appointment was scheduled. App asked for insurance, and that was it. Tech showed up in service time. Fixed the window fast, answered a bunch of questions we had about features, and then was off. No muss, no fuss. Mobile service was AWESOME! Oh, total cost to us was $0. Fit and finish great. Driving in rain great. 500-mile road trip with family of four great. Total cost, $16. Time at charging station, 14 min from 30% to 95%. People complain about no CarPlay/Android Auto, non-issue. Chevrolet navigation is outstanding. Phone Bluetooth connects for calls. Connectivity lets you connect to streaming services you subscribe to. Don't care about CarPlay/Android Auto anymore, it's irrelevant. You do have to take some time to learn how to use everything but it's time well spent as there's sooo much there for you to tailor the truck to how you want things. Chevrolet Silverado 3500. Two months, 2000 miles. Loving it. Can't wait for our other vehicle to have an issue, so we can justify getting another Silverado.

I purchased the Chevrolet Colorado single cab with an extended bed, & the 2.7 liter 6 cylinder. Everything was great. I bought the truck because my previous vehicle was getting a lot of miles & having issues. Needed something reliable. On my way home from work, I stopped at the grocery store, when I was ready to leave, I turn the key & it wouldn't start or even crank up at all. My display was showing multiple faults like brakes, camera, blind spot lights, among many other faults. The brake lights came on and wouldn't shut off until the battery went completely dead. It was 7pm. I went to the Chevrolet app & ordered a tow truck which did not arrive. By 1am I tried calling the tow truck company & they never answered. I called AAA which I should have done to begin with & even they didn't show up until 6am. I sat in my truck for 11 hrs in the grocery store parking lot totally stranded. By 8am I called the Chevrolet dealer to get a tow truck to my house & was furious by that point. A tow truck arrived a couple hours later to take the truck to the dealer I bought it from. The dealer tells me there's 35 vehicles ahead of me waiting for service & it will be a while before they could even look at my truck. It's been 5 days & they still haven't looked at it. The day I bought the truck the sales person told me I wouldn't have any problems but if I did, they would take care of me immediately. So glad I didn't trade in my previous vehicle because I'm self-employed & would be losing a lot of money and business. I bought my 2024 Colorado just 6 weeks ago and it's already broke down and unusable! Here I am paying for a brand new truck I can't even use! Wishing now that I never would have bought it!! Total let down!!

The vehicle's automatic engine stop-start system, which activates upon brake application, is a feature I find undesirable, despite the option to disable it. The vehicle lacks fog lights. It appears that SiriusXM is no longer available as a direct option, and the only way to access it is through streaming. It includes numerous options that are often offered as add-ons by other manufacturers.

I bought the 2026 Acura TL Hybrid Sport just two days ago, and I'm already extremely frustrated. Before this, I owned a 2017 Ford Explorer Limited, and the difference in quality is simply shocking. The TL's interior feels rushed and careless: cheap, rough plastics, poorly cut panels with even sharp edges. The lower dashboard is so thin and flimsy it feels like it could break with a light touch. The carpet is embarrassingly low quality, and the trunk is poorly designed, with no molded lining to organize the space. To make matters worse, the tailgate doesn't even open with the remote—something that should be standard in any modern car. The infotainment system is laughably basic, with very few features for a car at this price point. The USB ports are outdated and slow—and in 2026, not including a fast-charging USB-C is downright ridiculous. On top of that, there are no parking sensors, neither front nor rear, a feature that has become standard even in much cheaper vehicles. For nearly $40,000, the least you expect is quality and attention to detail. Instead, it feels like Acura only cared about cutting costs to increase profit. The result is a car that looks and feels cheap but is sold at a premium price. Sadly, this purchase has been a huge disappointment.

I've owned this Jeep Grand Wagoneer for nearly 4 months and initially had no issues. In the past month, I've encountered numerous problems related to the electronics and many of the vehicle's features associated with them. Specifically: Dashboard displays blank out or change to other screens without any input from me. The Lane Departure Assist was deactivated twice and turned itself back on both times after a period of weeks. I hate this feature and finding it back on... I was not pleased. The seat slide and driver's seat programming have stopped functioning, repeatedly. While driving on the highway, Cruise Control has turned on without any action on my part. It scared the crap out of me when the vehicle suddenly accelerated in heavy traffic. Apple CarPlay keeps disconnecting, and I have to reconnect it manually. All of my radio presets have erased and had to be reset - which is not easy in this vehicle. Frequently, the car does not recognize me as the driver (I think it links with my phone) and thinks I am a guest driver. The last time was when I took it to a carwash and someone else drove it in and out of the tunnel. When I got in, much of my programming was gone. It has TOO MANY features, and they are highly distracting. This is my 3rd Jeep, and I liked my previous models much better. I wish I'd kept my last one.

Specifically: Dashboard displays blank out or change to other screens without any input from me. The Lane Departure Assist was deactivated twice and turned itself back on both times after a period of weeks. I hate this feature and finding it back on was frustrating. The seat slide and driver's seat programming have stopped functioning repeatedly. While driving on the highway, Cruise Control has activated without any action on my part, which scared me when the vehicle suddenly accelerated in heavy traffic. Apple CarPlay keeps disconnecting, and I have to reconnect it manually. All of my radio presets have erased and had to be reset, which is not easy in this vehicle. Frequently, the truck does not recognize me as the driver (I think it links with my phone) and thinks I am a guest driver. The last time was when I took it to a carwash and someone else drove it in and out of the tunnel. When I got back in, much of my programming was gone. It has TOO MANY features, and they are highly distracting. This is my 3rd Colorado. I liked my previous model much better. I wish I'd kept it.

I purchased a 2025 Toyota Prius on 3/29/25 and after one day of driving I'm ready to trade it off. 30k down the drain! My wife & I test drove it locally around the dealership and never took it out on the highway and that's where we made a huge mistake. MONSTER MISTAKE! Anything over 40 mph and the people in the backseat won't be able to talk to each other or have a conversation with the people in the front. Anything over 55 mph on a concrete highway and you can't hear the stereo unless it's at half volume, and forget about having any type of conversation. It's noisy!! All the previous reviews that complain about the braking and lighting issues are correct. As we left the dealership I about had an accident when the lane assist yanked the steering wheel and I about swerved into a passing car. Super scary and I'm glad my 16-year-old daughter wasn't driving it. I'm 55 and I've bought roughly 15 new cars in my time and this is by far the biggest disappointment. I gave it two stars because it looks nicer than the competitors but that's being generous. It's prettier than the competitors but drivability and road noise are a serious issue with the 2025 Toyota Prius.

My Yukon history goes back 50 years to a new 1976 GMC Jimmy, I also had an '80 and '83 of that generation. New baby, low income at the time, long commute, dependable were key considerations. 40 years go by and I got the next GMC - a 2024 Yukon Denali last January after "growing up" and selling my Ford Explorer. I was able to negotiate $3,000 off sticker for the hybrid in mid December - at $72,000 this is a steal.

I had a 2015 Subaru Outback and after 75K miles, it finally let me down while towing a 2,500 lb camper, and it was going to be at least a week as no one could figure out what was wrong. Well, they still offered me over 5,000 bucks more than a year ago on a trade, and this new Crosstrek was sitting there at a price right in line with what I bought six years ago for financing. So, what has changed in five years? Well, it’s a bit more refined. I didn't know that but I feel it every time I drive it. There are definitely more features for sure. So, what stands out? It is the comfortable feel of this compact SUV. I mean, it is so smooth driving it, it's amazing. It is quiet inside, and my dogs love the back with their extra space when the seats are up out of the way. The Crosstrek is NOT my daily driver anymore and is mostly dedicated to light towing and some light off-roading in interesting places here in Montana. It certainly has the capabilities to do that, so now it is just seeing how it does over time. First impressions are a highly refined but still rugged vehicle. I got it to tow and it has the tow package. THAT I like, including the trailer TPMS monitor. The extra storage features I didn't really want were the roof rails and the new hatch design. OK, two weeks into it and I am really starting to like them. The roof rails are useful and for my needs, don't get in the way of space inside. AND, going to the transfer station I can open the hatch and reach everything easily instead of having to stretch to get stuff. OH, get the premium light package period. The LED headlights are worth their weight in gold compared to the old ones. Make that a must. But if gas mileage is a problem for you? Get a different vehicle. Well, I got rid of the Outback. Not because I had a problem as such, but because it didn’t tow my 3,000 lb camper as well as I needed. I bought a "22" Crosstrek in the same color and love it. So, IF you do NOT tow over 3,000 lbs, I would actually go for a Crosstrek over a larger SUV. The Crosstrek in the Premium trim and up is essentially a comfortable daily driver with some very good capabilities for light towing...up to around 3K in perfect comfort. The ride vs a larger SUV is amazing. The larger SUVs are trucks and ride like trucks. They have the comfortable interior but less room in the back as my dogs will attest to. I loved my Outbacks, both of them, but IF you are going to tow and generally go above 3K on your trailer, you might want to consider a larger SUV. It is a completely different "towing" experience...in a good way. A larger SUV will be more "planted" and less subject to the wind. A Crosstrek never lets you forget you are towing...something that big... A larger SUV gives you a bit more peace of mind and less stress... But basically, on both of them, I was happy...

I like this truck very much. I look forward to driving it and look for excuses to take trips and haul things around. So, let me just focus on the Cons: - The ride can be jarring on rough roads. (I do not have the adaptive suspension) Made more so by the off-road tires, which in principle I like. The off-road tires on a cold day on poorly maintained roads are not pleasant. - The wide pillars increase blind spots. But if that is a trade-off for safety in a crash, I'll take the wide pillars. - The back seat is comfortable but only adequately spacious. - No reclining rear seats. - The audio system is only adequate. - Steering can feel a little bit light and disconnected at times in some circumstances. - The single panel info screen looks a little awkward and could be better integrated. I think I prefer the two-screen setup with the "gauge cluster" in front of the driver. Knowing all this, I still chose this truck because all of the Pros easily outweigh the Cons. The Pros are well covered in all of the rave reviews this machine gets, and I concur. Note: The "safety" features are well integrated and easy to shut off. They stay off too, except for the greatest consumer hoax of all time, the Auto-Start-Stop "feature," appropriately, ASS. For this, you create a shortcut, and it's as easy to turn off as it was with the button. You can no longer "code" it out, as in previous models.

The tires on a cold day on poorly maintained paths are not pleasant. - The wide pillars increase blind spots. But if that is a trade-off for safety in a rollover, I'll take the wide pillars. - Back seat is comfortable but only adequately spacious. - No reclining rear seats. - The audio system is only adequate. - Steering can feel a little light and disconnected at times in certain conditions. - The single panel info screen looks a little awkward and could be better integrated. I think I prefer the dual-screen setup with the "gauge cluster" more visible in front of the driver. Knowing all this, I still chose this vehicle because all of the Pros easily outweigh the Cons. The Pros are well covered in all of the rave reviews this machine gets, and I concur. Note: The "safety" features are well integrated and easy to shut off. They stay off too, except for the greatest consumer hoax of all time, the Auto-Start-Stop "feature," appropriately, ASS. For this, you create a shortcut and it's as easy to turn off as it was with the button. You can no longer "code" it out, as in previous models.

Took delivery of a 2026 Toyota Highlander Hybrid in March. Within three weeks, an engine light came on ... software upgrade required, no big deal. However, by the end of June, when the summer heat had arrived and charging at 120v starts to become an issue ... it either doesn't charge after being plugged in for 10+ hours or, it sometimes even negative charges ... starts at 52% charged and the next day is at 27%! Several trips to service and they were not able to diagnose the problem, never mind fix it. But, I eventually learn it is a known issue that may be rectified with a software update, but no software update is imminent, and I'm welcome to travel to the dealership for a charge at 240v. Consequently, most of my summer driving has been on the gasoline engine. Checked the chat boards online and learned it has also been a problem with previous model years. Not impressed from a brand that is usually reliable.

We’ve had the car now for almost a year. Very pleased with the vehicle, less so with the dealer. No maintenance issues after about five thousand miles. The handling, acceleration, and technology are superb. It takes a while to learn the tech but that's true of ALL new vehicles. Most of it is pretty logical. A couple of minor nits: some glare from the driver's upper air vent reflecting into the side mirror should use black rather than silver. Too many button pushes instead of knobs for heat and air. The garage door refuses to pair with our opener; had no trouble with 6 other cars. The car DOES run fine on regular and despite the howls from the purists, it states right in the manual that using regular gas WILL NOT hurt the engine. Fuel mileage is outstanding for a vehicle of this weight and performance; I routinely get 32 mpg, even in traffic. Quiet and reliable. The dealership experience, however, both in purchase and in routine service leaves much to be desired. Toyota apparently only allows one dealer per midsized city and they can pretty much do as they please regarding add-ons and junk fees. I negotiated to get my price but it wasn't pleasant. They insisted on 5-star reviews when the delivery for a compact vehicle was 3.5 stars, maybe. The salesperson was upset when I gave them an honest review. A scheduled routine oil change took nearly 3 hours! Another 3-star review—no follow-up to ask why. I bought a second Toyota 9 months later because I was impressed with the car but drove two hours to use a different dealer. Much better treatment. Toyota management, are you listening?

Due to age and mileage, I needed to replace my wife's Mercedes R500, which has served us very well for dog hauling, long-distance family trips, and daily use over 90K miles, as well as my S430, which has been a great mile-eater but not used enough. With the nearest MB dealer 90 miles away, and the local indie mech crazy busy, changing brands was a necessity. After searching for a replacement for over a year and driving 20+ cars, the best choice to meet our needs was a 2026 Dodge Durango. It finally arrived last week, and the 2-for-1 deal was concluded with no hassle. I'm a car guy, mostly European sports and luxury, and I have to say the newest Dodge Durango is as competent as any MB, Saab, or BMW I've owned at a bargain price (for what it offers). Roomy, great seats, beautiful finishes, and so far impressive fuel efficiency. It's quieter than my S-class, as roomy as you can get in such a small footprint, and with tech and customization of features and drive modes as you can get. I hate CVTs - so the 8-speed automatic transmission (plus the available hybrid option) is great. Selectable regen is a plus (although when the smallish battery is charged it shuts off). The factory tires aren't the best, but they do seem to boost mileage - we'll see how they do in snow. Steering is light and precise - and road manners are excellent. Brakes are good. Visibility is excellent. The Durango's power is good for most situations - zippy around town, and easy passes on the highway. I'm surprised at how much the vehicle drives on electric power alone - with a very smooth transition to the gas engine. The new dash and instrument display is elegant and works great. Climate control is solid. We'll have to see how it is after a few months and more miles, but the initial impression it makes couldn't be better.

Purchased a 2025 Ford Focus hybrid in November 2024. The advertised mileage was 36/37, but after six months of driving, we're getting 26/27 and I'm not a fast driver. That and there are several design problems - the start button is hidden behind the steering wheel, the rear turn signals are a foot off the ground, and if we push the button on the rear hatch to close it, we have to wait until it's fully closed before we can get in the car. Otherwise, it opens up again and we can't close it using the button inside the car. Extremely annoying when you're standing in pouring rain waiting for the hatch to close. We traded in our Subaru Outback, which we loved, and paid extra for this hybrid in order to get better gas mileage. The non-hybrid Outback got better mileage; I'd never buy another Ford again.

Love the very impressive gas mileage but that's about it. The seat isn't the most comfortable with the front edge of the driver's seat high and firm for those that drive with their legs extended, and there is no way to adjust it lower. If you drive close to the wheel with knees bent, that shouldn't be a problem. The "lane assist" must be the worst idea anyone has ever had. Hate having the steering wheel (car) try to take control. The first time it happened was disturbing. It felt like I had to literally fight to control the car where I wanted to go when giving bicycle riders extra room as I passed. Good thing it can be disabled! I found the shifting to be somewhat harsh going into second and third gear when gently accelerating but seems to be improving both on the gentle and more normal accelerations after 850 miles. It rides over bumps and road imperfections more like a truck than a sedan. Road noise was okay, but when a rear window is fully opened, the interior suffers from a pulsating air compression effect where waves or blasts of air permeate. Very annoying.

I got a 2024 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray, and I'm really disappointed with the vehicle. I expected much better quality from Chevrolet, especially from the Corvette. First of all, the quality of the interior could be much better. It's a little noisy, and the assembly feels subpar, like it was put together in a backyard. Secondly, after just 8,000 km, the vehicle started leaking oil from the oil pan. The service technician told me it's a common issue because Chevrolet stopped using a gasket on the oil pan and now relies only on silicone sealant. Another frustrating issue is the digital speedometer. I can't get used to it. When the sun is behind you, it's nearly impossible to see your speed while driving. Lastly, for a vehicle that costs over $100,000, it's unbelievable that it doesn't even come with a tire pressure monitoring system. I have to point out that this is in Canada. For the price of the vehicle, you'd think they could include such a basic feature.

The redesign of this SUV is what drew us to it. Spent an arm on a 2024 X3 M Sport which we loved for about 3 weeks. After that, where do I even start? I've only made 2 payments on this car and it has been nothing short of a nightmare. The transmission blew with only 900 miles on it, ruining my driveway. It leaked the entire transmission while parked overnight. The car has needed 3 alignments in the 2 months of ownership, along with some dealership mistakes resulting in scratches and rim rashes. With 1600 miles on it, the driving assist feature took me off the side of the highway and disengaged, almost sending me into the woods at 70 mph. On top of that, the car went into brake assist while merging onto the highway, coming to a complete stop from 50, almost causing another major accident. BMW has offered me 400 loyalty points for my inconvenience while having my SUV almost have the time of the car. I would not recommend this vehicle to my worst enemy. Between my family and my wife's, we have owned upwards of 30 BMW products, which I don't think I will ever purchase another one after this experience.

We have just over 2000 miles on our Durango, which is our third one. We drove from Illinois to Houston, and I will say that adaptive cruise control is one of those things that you didn't know you needed until you got it. It makes interstate driving much less tiring and I think safer as it allows you to better monitor what is going on around you. The tech is great. I can just say the destination and away we go, no punching in addresses. My one gripe is the tailgate. The kick was so much better. The new gate is not hands-free to close, which is when you really need it. And you need to stay away from the back of the car if you have the key and you don't want the tailgate to open. Also, the driver screen could be better designed. But most importantly, the Durango swallows cargo like nothing else.
